content.text: Calculate the time taken to reach a speed of \(28 \text{m/s}\)
Calculate the force required to produce this acceleration
Calculate the kinetic energy of the car when its speed is \(28 \text{m/s}\)
kinetic energy = .........
The electric car has an acceleration of \(2.9 \text{m/s}^2\) when it moves from rest
The combined mass of the car and its driver is \(1600 \text{kg}\)
The time taken for the car battery to be recharged from zero charge to full charge is \(8.3 \text{h}\). The charge is delivered to the battery by a charger with a current of \(32 \text{A}\)
Calculate the charge supplied by the charger
Under ideal conditions, the car can travel a maximum distance of \(390 \text{km}\) when the battery is fully charged
Suggest why, in normal use, the car needs to be recharged after travelling less than \(390 \text{km}\)
[Total: 10]
A battery provides energy to an electric car
State the main form of energy stored in the water behind the dam
Calculate the rate at which energy is transferred by the falling water
rate of energy transfer = .........
The power scheme supplies a current of 270A at a voltage of 6000V
Calculate the efficiency of the power scheme
efficiency = .........%
The water is released from the dam and falls a vertical height of \(410\mathrm{m}\) at a rate of \(480\mathrm{kg / s}\)
State one disadvantage of hydroelectric power schemes
State one other renewable source of energy
Hydroelectric energy is a renewable form of energy
Water is held behind a dam in a hydroelectric power scheme
Draw a vector diagram to determine the resultant of the forces exerted by the two ropes on the boat. State the scale you used
scale =
magnitude of resultant force =
Determine the mass of the boat
Fig. 3.1 shows a boat stored in a shed. The boat is suspended from the ceiling of the shed by two ropes
The tension \(T\) in each of the ropes is \(75\mathrm{N}\)
Force is a vector
Draw a circle around **two** other quantities in the list which are vectors
**acceleration** **density** **energy** **mass**
**momentum** **power** **refractive index**
Draw the path of one of the bright specks of light
Explain, in terms of forces and the motion of air molecules, the cause of the motion of the smoke particles
Fig. 4.1 shows apparatus used to observe the motion of smoke particles (Brownian motion)
The glass cell has light shining on it from the side
The smoke particles are seen as bright specks of light when looking through the microscope
Explain, in terms of molecules, why the internal energy of the air increases
The temperature of the air in a sealed glass container is increased
Define specific heat capacity
Calculate the mass of water in the bowl when it is placed in the freezer

The specific heat capacity of water is \(4200 \text{J} / (\text{kg}^\circ \text{C})\). The specific heat capacity of ice is \(2100 \text{J} / (\text{kg}^\circ \text{C})\). The specific latent heat of fusion of water is \(3.3 \times 10^5 \text{J} / \text{kg}\)
Calculate the energy given out as the water cools from \(5.0^\circ \text{C}\) to ice at \(-18.0^\circ \text{C}\)

A bowl contains \(500 \text{cm}^3\) of water at a temperature of \(5.0^\circ \text{C}\). The bowl of water is placed in a freezer for several hours. When the bowl is removed from the freezer, it contains ice at a temperature of \(-18.0^\circ \text{C}\). The density of water is \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\)
Fig. 6.1 shows crests of a plane water wave approaching a barrier with a gap
On Fig. 6.1, draw **three** crests of the water wave to the right of the barrier
Fig. 6.2 shows crests of a plane water wave in deep water approaching a region of shallow water
The water wave moves more slowly in shallow water
On Fig. 6.2, draw:
three crests of the water wave in the shallow water
2. the direction of travel of the wave in the shallow water
State two ways in which transverse waves differ from longitudinal waves
State a typical value of the speed of sound in water
Explain why sound travels faster in water than in air
Fig. 7.1 shows a plan view of a room. There is a plane mirror on one wall and a picture across the whole of wall AB
A person is standing at point X and is looking at the mirror. The person cannot see all of the picture on wall AB reflected in the mirror
There is a point P on wall AB which is the closest point to A that the person can see reflected in the mirror
On Fig. 7.1, draw a reflected ray and an incident ray to show the position of the point P.
State two properties of the image formed by the mirror
shorter wavelengths than visible light
longer wavelengths than visible light
Visible light is an electromagnetic wave

current = .........

The number of turns on the secondary coil is 36 000

number of turns = .........
Explain why the readings in Table 10.1 are **not** the same as those plotted on the graph
Using the graph in Fig. 10.1, determine the half-life of this isotope of protactinium
The nuclide notation for this isotope of protactinium is \(^{234}_{91}\mathrm {Pa}\)
Protactinium-234 decays to an isotope of uranium (U) by \(\beta \)-emission
Write down the nuclide equation for this decay of protactinium-234
A student places a sample of an isotope of protactinium (Pa-234) near a radiation detector. The readings on the detector, taken every 20 s, are recorded in Table 10.1
Fig. 10.1 shows a graph of the count rate **due to this sample** against time
